xmlns=""><GeoBndBox esriExtentType="search"><exTypeCode Sync="TRUE">1</exTypeCode><westBL Sync="TRUE">-115.187620</westBL><eastBL Sync="TRUE">-115.004353</eastBL><northBL Sync="TRUE">44.370153</northBL><southBL Sync="TRUE">44.249107</southBL></GeoBndBox></geoEle></dataExt><idPurp>An aboveground tree carbon map.</idPurp><idAbs><DIV STYLE="text-align:Left;"><DIV><DIV><P><SPAN><SPAN>Aboveground tree carbon was mapped by applying a multiple linear regression model that predicted field observations of aboveground tree carbon from LiDAR metrics.</SPAN></SPAN></P><P><SPAN /></P></DIV></DIV></DIV></idAbs><idCredit>Idaho NSF EPSCoR, University of Idaho</idCredit><searchKeys><keyword>carbon</keyword><keyword>LiDAR</keyword><keyword>multiple linear regression</keyword></searchKeys><dataChar><CharSetCd value="004" /></dataChar><suppInfo>Field observations of tree basal area, gathered within circular plots, were converted to carbon using allometry. LiDAR metrics of LiDAR data coincident with plot extents were created, and multiple linear regression models predicting aboveground tree carbon from LiDAR metrics were created. Cross-validated multiple linear regression models explained 84% of variation in aboveground carbon. The model was then applied to 20-m lidar metric grids to map aboveground tree carbon across the LiDAR acquisition area. Areas above 2150 m and within 91 meters of roads were masked in final maps. For details see Bright, B.C., Hicke, J.A., and Hudak, A.T. 2012. Estimating aboveground carbon stocks of a forest affected by mountain pine beetle in Idaho using lidar and multispectral imagery. Remote Sensing of Environment, 124: 270-281 and Bright, B.C., Hicke, J.A., and Hudak, A.T. 2012. Landscape-scale analysis of aboveground tree carbon stocks affected by mountain pine beetles in Idaho. Environmental Research Letters, 7, 045702.</suppInfo><idStatus><ProgCd value="001" /></idStatus><tpCat><TopicCatCd value="002" /></tpCat><tpCat><TopicCatCd value="006" /></tpCat><tpCat><TopicCatCd
